_header: Most christian Princess by influence of grace
Subjects: pageant verses; occasional verse; Margaret, queen of England
_description: Pageant Verses for Queen Margaret’s Entry into London (1445) probably by Lydgate — 170 lines in rhyme royal and 8-line stanzas (ababbcbc), seven items in all

BLHar542.First Lines:
Moost cristen princesse by influence of gracedoughter of Iherusalem
                    owr plesaunce…
BLHar542.Last Lines:
…with fruition of the Trinitieby contemplation of his
                    glorie
BLHar542.Note:
Seven stanzas only (lines 1-39, 155-70), each with an English and Latin
                    heading to explain where the stanza would be read, e.g., ‘At leden hall
                    madam grace Chaunceler de diem’ (f. 101v); ends ‘deo
                        gracias Amen’ on next line after last line (f. 102); written in
                    the hand of John Stow.
BLHar542.Attributed Title:
The speches in the pagiants at þe comynge of qwene margaret wyfe to
                    henry the syxt of that name kynge of england the 28 of maye in the yere of owr
                    lorde 1445 þe 23 of hys reigne (f. 101)
BLHar542.Editions:
Withington,  Robert. 
             “Queen Margaret’s Entry into London, 1445.” 
             Modern Philology
         13 (1915-16): 53-7: 55-7.

BLHar3869.First Lines: Most cristen Princesse by influence of graceDoughter of Ierusalem oure plesaunce…
BLHar3869.Last Lines: …With fruicioun of the TryniteBy contemplacioun of hys glorie
BLHar3869.Note: At top of page, “Atte the Brigge foot in Suthwerke / Pees and plente” (f. 2); ends “deo gracias Amen” (f. 4v).
